title: About
text:
This blog will contain somewhat technical thoughts around software, systems, and control.
Of particular interest is dynamic programming. We will try to get the gist of it, and especially to figure out how we can see similarities between how it is used in control and how it is used in computer science.

title: A Quarto Book
text:
Here is how I created a book using Quarto.
I started with installing Quarto, using the downloadable file found on the Quarto Get Started page.
Starting out with R Studio as the IDE, thinking that this was the only option, I switched to using VSCode.
Using the VSCode Quarto extension, I could now create a book, using Command-Shift-P (I am on a Mac) and the choosing the function Quarto: Create Project.
This led to a book with two chapters, a reference section with a reference to Donald E Knuthâ€™s Literate Programming.
I could render the book, in html and pdf, using the command (in the VSCode Terminal)
quarto render
The pdf rendering relied on LaTeX, which I installed from this MacTex page.
You can read about LaTex recommendations for Quarto in the Quarto docs.
The book can be viewed, in a browser, by issuing the command
quarto preview
The pdf version of the book can be found in the directory _book (which was created as a result of the quarto render command)


Looking in the file _quarto.yml, I found placeholders for title and author, as
  title: "intocontrol_book"
  author: "Norah Jones"
I changed those, and also the date, which was on the line below where the author was stated.



I wrote some equations, in the intro.qmd file, using LaTex as I learned it when I was working in University.
Using the notation
$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot x &= Ax + Bu \\
y &= Cx + Du
\end{aligned}
$$
I got a nicely displayed equation, however without any equation number.
Changing the notation, with inspiration from Stack Overflow and the Quarto documentation, to
$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot x &= Ax + Bu \\
y &= Cx + Du
\end{aligned}
$${#eq-state-space}
I saw that an equation number appeared.

title: Averaging in discrete time
text:
I am reading the excellent book Lectures on Network Systems by Francesco Bullo.
My goal is to learn more about dynamic systems that are built up as networks, and also how one can control such systems.


In the first chapter of the book, there is a section where network systems that do averaging are described.
A network system can be described by an undirected graph.

title: Averaging in discrete time
text:
Analysis
Given an initial state \(x(0)\), one might wonder what happens with \(x(k)\) as the time \(k\) increases?
For example, will \(x\) converge to a specific value? And if this happens, what would the value be?
One could also wonder, if such a convergence happens, how long time (how many iterations) it would take?

title: Averaging in discrete time
text:
Simulation
We could answer our questions about what happens when time goes on, somewhat empirically, by making a computer simulation of the dynamic system \((1)\).
We decide to use Python, with numpy and matplotlib.
A class, representing a dynamic system, can be created as
class DynamicSystem:

    def __init__(self, A, x0):
        self.A = A
        n_rows, n_cols = A.shape
        assert n_rows == n_cols
        self.n = n_rows
        assert len(x0) == self.n
        self.x = x0

    def run(self, n_steps):
        # the result, as a matrix where each column represents x,
        # for the initial value and for the n_steps steps
        x_res = np.zeros([self.n, n_steps+1])
        x_res[:, [0]] = self.x
        for i in range(n_steps):
            nx = np.matmul(self.A, self.x)
            x_res[:, [i+1]] = nx
            self.x = nx
        return x_res
We can simulate this system, with an \(A\) matrix as used above and with an initial \(x\) chosen as \[
x_0=
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2
\end{bmatrix}^T
\] for five steps, by writing a function, as
def line():
    A = np.array([[1/2, 1/2], [1/2, 1/2]])
    x0 = np.array([[1, 2]]).T
    d_sys = DynamicSystem(A, x0)
    x_res = d_sys.run(5)
    print(x_res)
Running this function gives a printout, as
python3 simulate.py
[[1.  1.5 1.5 1.5 1.5 1.5]
 [2.  1.5 1.5 1.5 1.5 1.5]]
where we see that each of the components in \(x\) converge to the average of the components of the initial value \(x_0\).
We also see that the convergence takes only one step.
